title: Simmer Guide
text:
Simmer
With simmer, you can use block programming to simulate probability experiments, among other things.
This guide assumes you have some CODAP skills:

You can make graphs.
You can make a new attribute (a new column) and give it a simple formula.

Do the three lessons you can see in the sidebar.

Simmer in a new tab
If you want to experiment outside of this guide, click the link below to open a simmer document in a new tab. You’ll have more space.
Bookmark it so you can simmer again whenever you want.
  a fresh simmer document

title: simmer
text:
One die
We will begin by rolling one die
Make the program you see below. Notice how the blocks fit together. We have a block that represents a variable (named item), and it “receives” a random number. Then we send that data to CODAP.

In the live example below, try to build that program. Some hints:

The gray stripe on the left is called the toolbox.
The toolbox contains the names of categories. Click on a name to see the blocks in that category.
Find the blocks you need in three different categories.
Drag blocks from the toolbox into the main workspace and hook them together.
If you get one you don’t want, you can drag it to the trash can in the lower right.

See how you do:




When you have it the way you want, press the run button (the green circle). A CODAP table appears with your data in it. Run the program a few more times and see how the value of item changes.
Because it’s in CODAP, you can make a graph the usual way.



Does item look evenly distributed? (Probably not!)

title: simmer
text:
Two dice
One die is great…but what could be better? Two dice! More than twice as good.
We give you a fresh, blank simmer document below. You can start fresh right there or modify what you did above. Try to make a program like this one:







Names are important



Give your variables meaningful names. Names like die and die2 tell you what’s going on.
When we were just getting started, we used the default name, item. That’s a terrible name for a variable!


Here are some tips:

Use the yellow “plus” button near the top-left of the simmer window to make the variables die1 and die2.
After you make a block that sets a variable, you can use the menu in that variable block to change which variable it refers to. You can also use that menu to change the variable’s name.





When you run your program, simmer will create a column in your CODAP table for every variable in your program. That means you can calculate the sum of the two dice in CODAP.

make a new column with a formula for the sum of the two dice.
make a graph of that sum.

If you know the theory, you know it’s suppose to look like a pyramid. Does it look the way you expect? Is seven the most popular sum?
If not, add a few hundred cases. See if it gets closer to the “official” result.
Now for something really cool:

Imagine a graph with die1 plotted against die2. Stop and think: what will that graph look like?
Make a new graph and do that plot. Did it look the way you expected?

Did you collapse your code so that you could see the graph better? Don’t forget that tip!

In the graph of sum, select all the cases with a sum of 5.

Your screen might now look something like this:


Look at the other graph, and think about what that means. Use selection in this way to make a convincing argument why seven is the most common result, and why 2 and 12 are the rarest.


Reflecting
You made a probability model using simmer, simulating throws of two dice.
Using a “repeat” block—a loop structure— you could throw lots of dice, many more than would be practical in real life.
Finally, you used the results to learn more about how probability works.

title: simmer
text:
Repeating many times
Let’s change the program so that it repeats that process on its own, so that we don’t have to press the button so many times.
Improve the example below.

Find a “repeat” block in one of the categories that will run those blocks 10 times.
Drag it into the workspace and make it enclose the blocks you want to repeat.
Run it and see what happens. (It’s probably still not very evenly distributed.)
Change the number of repeats to a few hundred and run it again.
See if the graph shows that item has a more even distribution.





The screen is getting crowded. It’s hard to work with the program, the graph, and the table at the same time.






pro tip: collapsing the code



In the simmer top bar you’ll see a [currently brown] square showing four arrows pointing inward. Press it to collapse the program so you have more space for data analysis.
Then, when you want to program again, press the button to give yourself room to code.
